item.title: Understanding RTO and RPO in disaster recovery
item.description: In today‚Äôs digital landscape, where downtime can cost businesses thousands of dollars per minute, having a robust disaster recovery (DR) strategy is non-negotiable. Two fundamental metrics in any business continuity plan are recovery time objective (RTO) and recovery point objective (RPO). These determine how quickly a system can recover after a failure and how much data a company is willing to lose in the process.

item.title: S3 is not a backup: why you need a real backup strategy
item.description: Let us get straight to the point: Amazon S3 is a phenomenal service for scalable, reliable object storage but it is not a backup solution. Sure, S3 boasts rock-solid durability and cost efficiency, but relying on it alone for backups is like trying to cover your bases with duct tape. In today‚Äôs world, where a single misclick can spell disaster, a thoughtful, multi-layered backup strategy is not just nice to have; it is absolutely essential.

item.title: Why replication is not backup
item.description: In the realm of data protection, backup and replication are two fundamental strategies employed to safeguard information. While they share the common goal of data preservation, they operate on distinct principles and serve different purposes. Understanding these differences is crucial for developing a robust data protection strategy.

item.title: The 3-2-1 backup rule: A proven strategy for data protection
item.description: Data loss can happen in many ways: whether due to accidental deletion, cyberattacks, hardware failure, or even a catastrophic event like a data center fire. To protect against these risks, IT professionals have long relied on the 3-2-1 backup rule, a fundamental strategy for ensuring data resilience.
